bibl.title: Surgeon General's Office Record Card, January 20, 1913

div1.p: Excerpts from a record card pertain to the biographies of Walter Reed, as well as to the discussion of a monument to commemorate the completion of the Panama Canal that should include Walter Reed. The record card is dated from January 20, 1913 through June 28, 1913. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Surgeon General's Office Record Card, January 20, 1913
div1.p:
Hon. Wn. N. McKinley, H.R. Wash. D.C. Jan. 16
1913. States he has a requests from
Dr/Charles B. Johnson of Champaign,
Ill. for a copy of a biography of
Dr. Walter Reed. Would appreciate it
very much if a copy of this biography
could be sent to Dr. Johnson.
Surg. Gen. P.H.S. Jan. 18, 1913. Refers
to the S.G. of the Army and the writ-
er so informed.

12
Jan. 20, 1913.
Dr. Charles B. Johnson,
Champaign, Ill. Sir: In accordance with
a request from Hon. Wm. B. McKinley, M. C.,
I am sending you herewith a copy of
Senate Document No. 822, entitled “Yel-
low Fever; a compilation of the re-
sults of the work of Maj. Walter Reed,
M.C., U.S.A., and the Yellow Fever Com-
mission”, which contains all the
literature in this office on this sub-
ject available for distribution. A
book entitled “Walter Reed and Yellow
Fever”, by Howard A. Kelly was published
by McClure, Phillips & Co., New York,
1906. This is a book of about 300
pages.

13-A. June 3, 1913. Dr. Albert Woldert,
Tyler, Tex.

My Dear Dr. Woldert: I have your let-
ter of May 31 with the resolution
proposing that the method of commemo-
rating the completion of the Panama
Canal be by memorials to Col. Ronald
Ross, Royal Army Med. Corps, and Col. Wm.
G. Gorgas, M.C., U.S.A.

Within the lost two weeks I have
written a letter to Dr. Dyer proposing
that the memorial should be in form
of a monument in Washington to Maj.
Walter Reed and Col. Gorgas. It is not
entirely clear to me why Ross should
be memorialized on account of his
work in India, and Reed should be omit-
ted when his investigations of a simi-
lar character in Cuba were distinctly
responsible for the control of yellow
fever in Cuba and Panama. If you
think that Ross should be remembered
on account of the fact that malaria
is as formidable an enemy in the trop-
ics as yellow fever, the monument
might be erected to all three. Lazear
Carroll, and LePrince could be also re-
membered with bas-reliefs on the
base of the monument.

A bill was introduced in Congress
some years ago by Senator Owen to
erect a monument to Walter Reed and
his coadjutors but nothing has yet
come of it. The sum of $25,000, was
likewise raised by subscription by
the Walter Reed Memorial Association
but it is tied up for an indefinite
period by a provision that the inter-

est on this sum is to go to his widow
during her lifetime.

I will be glad to join in your scheme
providing Maj. Reed comes in on an equal
footing with the other two. I know
Col. Gorgas very intimately and believe
that this would be in accordance with
his wishes.

Yale University Press, New Haven, Conn
June, 27, 1913. In his new book on the
“Evolution of Modern Medicine”, Sir
William Osler especially commends the
work of the Commission in Cuba which
was headed by Major Walter Reed, and
he wishes to include in his book, pic-
tures of each of its members.

The only photographs of Major Reed and
Dr. James Carroll in his possession are
very poor, and it is his desire that we
as publishers secure better originals
of them. We write, therefore, to ask you
to advise us where such pictures would
be procurable and to whom to apply for
them.
